Definition: The input contains an argument and a keypoint on the topic "We should abolish intellectual property rights", separated by "<sep>".Your task is to answer if the keypoint matches the argument and summarizes exactly what the argument means, in the context of this topic.

Positive Examples.input: Argument: A song or writing are works of art and their creators should benefit from them<sep>Keypoint: People, or a business, own their innovations and should be able to be compensated for their endeavour
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that a song or writing are works of art and their creators should benefit from them

Positive Examples.input: Argument: We need to do away with intellectual property rights so it doesn't slow down innovation<sep>Keypoint: Intellectual property restricts access to important information/products
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that we need to do away with intellectual property rights so it doesn't slow down innovation

Positive Examples.input: Argument: Intellectual property rights ensure that people or companies can make profits from what they have spent much time and effort in creating.<sep>Keypoint: Intellectual property rights incentivize creativity/innovation
Positive Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that intellectual property rights ensure that people or companies can make profits from what they have spent much time and effort in creating.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: There is no reason to abolish these rights because, if a person came up with an idea, they should get credit for it<sep>Keypoint: Intellectual property rights incentivize creativity/innovation
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint does not summarize the argument that there is no reason to abolish these rights because, if a person came up with an idea, they should get credit for it

Negative Examples.input: Argument: Intellectual property rights protect someone's research and hard work ensuring that they can be recognized and recompensed for their efforts.<sep>Keypoint: People, or a business, own their innovations and should be able to be compensated for their endeavour
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that intellectual property rights protect someone's research and hard work ensuring that they can be recognized and recompensed for their efforts.

Negative Examples.input: Argument: If abolished it will stiffle creativity and advancement because there will be no incentive if intellectual property is not a right.<sep>Keypoint: Intellectual property rights incentivize creativity/innovation
Negative Examples.explanation: The keypoint summarizes the argument that if abolished it will stiffle creativity and advancement because there will be no incentive if intellectual property is not a right.
